englishTranslation: How have you not ever been there?
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
cómo: adverb meaning "how?" in a question or implied question
has: "have", "you have" before a participle (Haber, present, 2nd person)

englishTranslation: How much do we have to help? With everything?
vocabIncluded: cuánto: adverb meaning "how much?" in a question or implied question
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

englishTranslation: Where did he have to work that day?
vocabIncluded: dónde: adverb meaning "where?" in a question or implied question
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

englishTranslation: All good? There is a need to finish this soon.
vocabIncluded: hay: "there is/are" indicating existence (Haber, present, impersonal)
using Haber with "que" to indicate that there's a need to do something

englishTranslation: There was a need to do that.
vocabIncluded: había: "there was/were" indicating existence (Haber, imperfect, impersonal)
using Haber with "que" to indicate that there's a need to do something

spanishExample: Mis amigos me tenían que *help* con esto.
englishTranslation: My friends had to help me with this.
vocabIncluded: using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: No habrá que hacer algo tan *extreme.*
englishTranslation: There won’t be a need to do something so extreme.
vocabIncluded: habrá: "there will be" indicating existence (Haber, future, impersonal)
tan: "so" as an adverb right before an adjective or adverb
using Haber with "que" to indicate that there's a need to do something

spanishExample: No lo tendrá que hacer otra vez.
englishTranslation: She won’t have to do it again.
vocabIncluded: tendrá: "will have", "he/she/it will have" (Tener, future, 3rd person)
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: No tendré que hacer mucho ahí.
englishTranslation: I won’t have to do much there.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
tendré: "will have", "I will have" (Tener, future, 1st person)
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Siempre tienes que ser mejor que el día *before.*
englishTranslation: You always have to be better than the day before.
vocabIncluded: using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Solo tendrán que estar ahí a 7, ya que *the movie starts* a 8.
englishTranslation: They will only have to be there at 7, since the movie starts at 8.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
tendrán: "will have", "they will have" (Tener, future, 3rd person plural)
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation
ya que: idiom meaning "since" in a logical sense

spanishExample: Tengo que *cook the food* para *the party.*
englishTranslation: I have to cook the food for the party.
vocabIncluded: using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Tenía que ir, pero no lo *I did.*
englishTranslation: I had to go, but I didn’t do it.
vocabIncluded: using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

englishTranslation: You had to be on time.
vocabIncluded: using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

englishTranslation: She has to apologize upon making a mistake.
vocabIncluded: using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Tiene que haber *enough food* para todos.
englishTranslation: There has to be enough food for everyone.
vocabIncluded: haber: "there to be" indicating existence (Haber, infinitive)
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

englishTranslation: They have to know the truth.
vocabIncluded: using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Ya está, lo tuve que hacer por mi amigo.
englishTranslation: It's done, I had to do it on behalf of my friend(m).
vocabIncluded: using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation
ya está: idiom meaning "it's done", "all done", etc.
